header.name: chaos/preprocessor/algorithm/fold_right_aux.h
header.author: Paul Mensonides
header.overview: The header defines an algorithm that accumulates the elements of a from the last element to the first element.

macro.abstract: The macro accumulates the elements of its second argument with the operation specified by its first argument.

param.para:
The operation that is to be used to accumulate the elements of g. This operation must be either a or a macro name that refers to a macro with a signature compatible with the following pseudo-signature:
op(s, elem1, data2, state3)
1 If the type of g is non-variadic, elem must be the number of parameters that corresponds to the number of sub-elements in each element of g. Otherwise, elem must be a single parameter.

2 If the auxiliary data is parenthetic, the data pseudo-parameter must be the number of parameters that corresponds to the number of sub-elements in the auxiliary data. Otherwise, it must be a single parameter.
3 The state pseudo-parameter must be either ... or the number of parameters that corresponds to the number of arguments in the initial state, __VA_ARGS__.

macro.para:
The macro itself expands to a in terms of (s). This , when invoked by , expands to the result of accumulating the elements of g, from right to left, with the user-specified operation. This is illustrated by the following pseudo-code:
op(s, g[0], data, op(s, g[1], data, ... op(s, g[length(g) - 1], data, state) ... ))

An invocation of the operation with the current (s), a particular element (elem), the auxiliary data (data), and the current state (state or __VA_ARGS__) expands to a new state used in the accumulation of subsequent elements (or as the final result of the algorithm if no further elements exist). This operation may also expand to a in terms of (s) that expands to a new state. Expansion to a allows the operation to recurse on itself if necessary.
Invocations of the operation are trampolined such that each invocation is invoked with ((s)), where s is the original at the beginning of the algorithm (i.e. ()). This maximizes the utility of the .

The auxiliary data, data, is treated differently depending on whether it is parenthetic. If data is non-parenthetic, it is passed directly to the operation as a single argument. In C99, if data is a parenthetic expression of any arity, its sub-elements are passed to the operation as individual arguments. In C (prior to C99) and C++, if data is a unary parenthetic expression, its sub-element is passed to the operation as a single argument (a parenthetic expression of any other arity is prohibited).

Ignoring the complexity of op (which is invoked once for each element in g), the running time of can be described in terms of the number of required to complete the algorithm. The asymptotic upper and lower bounds are Θ(n+1), where n is the number of elements in g.
